posts.name: Arnaud's
posts.note: Arnaud's is a tin-ceilinged 'grande dame' of Creole dining since 1918, featuring seafood classics and a jazz brunch. For dinner, I ordered the 'Alligator Sausage' appetizer, and for my main meal, I ordered the 'Crawfish O’Connor' which is baked in a Brandy-infused classic Creole tomato based sauce and served with Jasmine rice.

posts.name: Bevi Seafood Co.
posts.note: Bevi Seafood Co. is a market and eatery in no-nonsense quarters with fresh fish and oysters plus prepared foods like po' boys. Order the Cochon De Lait po’ boy which has Pecan smoked pork topped with Creole cole slaw, pickled peppers, and charred onion mayo or the Peacemaker po’ boy which contains Fresh Louisiana Shrimp, roast beef debris and Swiss cheese or some crayfish. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Bon Ton Café
posts.note: Bon Ton Café is a nostalgic, brick-walled spot is serving classic Cajun dishes since 1953, except on weekends. For an appetizer, I had the turtle soup and was great, but saltier than I thought it would be because the salt cuts down on the gaminess is what I read later. For my dinner, I had the 'Red Fish Bon Ton' which is red fish with crab on top.

posts.name: Bourrée at Boucherie
posts.note: Bourrée at Boucherie was a onetime food truck dispenses frozen daiquiris, spiced wings and Cajun specialties from a meat counter. You need to order the meat pie and spicy shrimp boudin with beef fat fries.

posts.name: Cafe Du Monde
posts.note: Cafe Du Monde is an iconic New Orleans cafe known for café au laits, chicory coffee and beignets since 1862. Like everyone else, I order a larger order of beignets with a hot chocolate because it was a cold day. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: The Camellia Grill
posts.note: The Camellia Grill is a fabled institution for diner fare dished out by bow-tied servers, plus late-night dining. The Camellia Grill is a landmark diner in the Carrollton section of New Orleans. It is on Carrollton Avenue near its intersection with St. Charles Avenue on the St. Charles Streetcar line Order the omelettes and the bacon cheeseburger.

posts.name: Carmo Cafe
posts.note: Carmo Cafe is an innovative, vegan-friendly fare with tropical influences in a cozy spot with an open kitchen. The author mentioned you need to order the shio koji platter, which are Japanese pickled things (tsukemono). From their website, 'The menu includes selections such as a Burmese Tea Leaf Salad, pão de queijo, acarajé and daily soups and specials from around the tropics. Carmo’s raw seafood menu features the region’s freshest fish prepared in a variety of styles, including shima sashimi (raw, flash-cured fish, a style common to Japan’s tropical islands), tiradito (a Peruvian version of sashimi, smothered in aji amarillo pepper sauce) and rum-cured, cold-smoked yellowfin tuna. There’s also a raw vegan menu which introduces diners to shio-koji style preparation, avocados, organic tofu, and other fresh vegetables lightly fermented using a koji (aspergillus oryzae) marinade, which almost magically imparts distinct umami characteristics to any food to which it is exposed. The beverage menu is equally as unique, featuring exotic fruit such as juice of the cocoa fruit (cacau), açerola, cupuaçu, graviola (sour sop), caja and caju, which infuse Carmo's juice and cocktail menu with exciting new flavors.'
posts.rcmmnd: The Fermented Man: A Year on the Front Lines of a Food Revolution - by Derek Dellinger

posts.name: Casamento's Restaurant
posts.note: Casamento's Restaurant is a cash-only spot serving fresh oysters and other seafood in a compact, mosaic-tiled space since 1919. NOTE: They are closed during the summer.

posts.name: Central Grocery
posts.note: Central Grocery is a small Italian market selling specialty foods and muffuletta sandwiches, which its founder invented.

posts.name: Clover Diner
posts.note: Clover Diner is retro-styled diner drawing crowds from neighboring gay bars with burgers and breakfast served 24/7. Great little hole-in-the-wall diner at the top of Bourbon Street in the French Quarter that is open 24 hours a day. Order yourself a cheeseburger and tater tots.

posts.name: Cochon Butcher
posts.note: Cochon Butcher is a stylish renovated warehouse serving elevated, pork-focused Cajun fare in a group-friendly setting. Established in 2009 in the New Orleans Warehouse District, Butcher is a butcher shop, a sandwich counter and a wine bar located next door to Cochon. Chefs Donald Link and Stephen Stryjewski offer small plates, daily lunch specials, and dinner entrees. Inspired by old-world meat markets, Butcher specializes in housemade meats, terrines, and sausages. Butcher offers an array of housemade pickles, jellies, jams, and sauces, as well as a carefully curated collection of handmade knives, cutting boards, and branded merchandise. Butcher’s charcuterie, sausage or cheese platters, and sandwich trays are available for catering needs.

posts.name: Cochon Restaurant
posts.note: Cochon Restaurant is a lauded choice in charming, historical digs specializing in pork dishes, and imaginative Cajun eats.

posts.name: Dian Xin
posts.note: Dian Xin serves freshly made baos, soup dumplings, Jian Bings, and many more things. Hong Kong native, Judy Ceng, brings authentic flavors of her hometown to New Orleans' French Quarter at Dian Xin. The menu features authentic Chinese fare such as dumplings, Szechuan chicken, dim sum and more. Hot Chinese Tea is served by the pot, and you can finish your meal off with a matcha chocolate lava cake.

posts.name: Domilise's Po-Boy and Bar
posts.note: Domilise's Po-Boy and Bar is a local institution with massive po' boys and beer in a no-nonsense counter-serve space since 1924. Helen Rosner recommends their golden fried shrimp in a po’ boy. From their website, 'In a quiet uptown neighborhood sits a small yellow house with a handpainted sign that reads, “Domilise's Po-Boys and Bar.” It's 10 am. The phone inside begins to ring furiously. A line of both locals and tourists alike forms on the corner of Annunciation and Bellecastle. By noon, the scent of fried shrimp and oysters can be smelled all the way to Tchoupitoulas Street. It's lunchtime. Domilise's is open, and Miss Dot is smiling from above while her beloved customers sit and enjoy their po-boys.'

posts.name: Dooky Chase's
posts.note: Dooky Chase's serves legendary Creole chef Leah Chase down-home staples in a vibrant, art-filled space. You need to order the gumbo or the fried chicken.

posts.name: Kermit's Treme Mother in Law Lounge
posts.note: Kermit's Treme Mother in Law Lounge has a catchy, warm environment. When you walk in you will always be greeted with a hot meal and a cold drink. Kermit's Treme Mother in Law Lounge has been host to many musicians from all over the world. We will continue to do so as the word spreads of the remarkable environment of Kermit's Treme Mother in Law Lounge. Come in and enjoy our cozy backyard with some of the best tasting BBQ or deep fried catfish in the city of Kenner, LA.

posts.name: Kingfish
posts.note: Kingfish serves contemporary spins on Southern dishes, classic cocktails, and wine in a vintage-looking environment.

posts.name: Mahony's Po-Boys and Seafood
posts.note: Mahony's Po-Boys and Seafood serves Po' boys that come big and loaded with fillings at this spacious, counter-serve sandwich shop and bar. You need to order the Peacemaker which contains fried jumbo gulf shrimp and oysters, cheddar cheese, bacon, and dressed or the Chicken Livers and Cole Slaw which has house dredge fried chicken livers, creole coleslaw, and creole mustard vinaigrette.

posts.name: Molly's Rise and Shine
posts.note: From the NOLA website, 'Molly’s Rise and Shine is the breakfast joint from chef Mason Hereford and his crew at Turkey and the Wolf. That’s the small sandwich shop with an outsized reputation for creative eats. The all-day breakfast menu shows the connection to Turkey and the Wolf with riffs on comfort food staples. The deviled egg tostada, for instance, is topped with spicy-tart pickled peppers, a peanut salsa, fresh cilantro, and a smooth spread made from deviled eggs. A pair of bagel plates arrive on plastic cafeteria trays, with spreads and toppings to assemble yourself.'

posts.name: Mosca's
posts.note: Mosca's is a nothing-fancy place serving hearty portions of family-style Italian fare since 1946. If you order the meatball, sauce, and spaghetti, you need to put the meatballs down first then the pasta with oysters Mosca on top or get the fried chicken.

posts.name: Neyow's Creole Cafe
posts.note: Neyow's Creole Cafe is an informal establishment supplying Creole and other Southern-inspired dishes along with cocktails. From the NOLA Eater website, 'Tanya Dubuclet and her family have been cooking and serving soul Creole food from her grandma's kitchen on the corner of Jeff Davis Parkway and Bienville since 2010. Neyow's sounds like New Orleans, too. Bartenders holler greetings to regulars when they walk in, and lunchtime conversations among customers are not necessarily confined to one table. If the food hits comfort food buttons, the atmosphere and attitude of the restaurant carries the same tune.'

posts.name: Parkway Bakery and Tavern
posts.note: Longtime (since 1911) neighborhood hangout with a patio known for classic-style po' boys. You have to get yourself one of their 'Shrimp Po Boy' with lettuce, tomato, and special sauce.
posts.cptn: Shrimp Po Boy with lettece, tomatoe, and special sauce from Parkway Bakery and Tavern in New Orleans, LA

posts.name: Piece of Meat
posts.note: Piece of Meat is a nose to tail butcher shop and restaurant located in New Orleans. From their website, 'We work with farmers that use responsible and humane methods. We try our best to put every part of the animal to good use. If you want something we don’t have, come talk to us- we want you to love eating our meat.'

posts.name: Pho Tau Bay Restaurant
posts.note: Pho Tau Bay Restaurant serves traditional Vietnamese cuisine in a contemporary space lined with exposed-brick walls.

posts.name: Port of Call
posts.note: Port of Call has hefty burgers, loaded baked potatoes, cocktails and a jukebox draw lines at this 50-year-old dive. The thing my friend that suggested Port of Call told me to order one of their burgers which are what they are known for.

posts.name: Red's Chinese
posts.note: Red's Chinese serves creative Chinese fare made with Southern twists in a simple setting with beer, wine, and cocktails too. You need to order the General’s Chicken which is fried chicken with ginger garlic sauce, peanut, and cilantro or an order of the cheeseburger fried rice.

posts.name: Rosalita’s Backyard Tacos
posts.note: From GQ Magazine's website about Rosalita’s Backyard Tacos, 'When Bywater American Bistro opened, it took over the space occupied by Mariza, a much-loved Italian restaurant owned by New Orleans restaurant veterans Laurie Casebonne and Ian Schnoebelen. Luckily it was a happy ending for all: a much-better-rested Schnoebelen and Casebonne opened a hole in the fence that separates their house from an alley housing a working voodoo temple, installed a counter, and started selling some of the city's best tacos on weekend days and Tuesday nights. The pulled pork shoulder taco is moist, smoky, and irresistible, as is one with battered and fried fish that will have you thinking you're in San Diego, which happens to be where Schnoebelen grew up. There's a small clearing with assorted lawn furniture to sit at farther down the alley, which is decorated with voodoo-themed drawings and paintings. Its name is Rosalie Alley, and it's located between two streets named Piety and Desire—which of course, is where most of us dwell nearly all the time.'
posts.hrs: Open Tuesday, Friday, and Saturday evening

posts.name: Ruby Slipper Cafe
posts.note: Ruby Slipper Cafe is a cheery cafe serving signature omelets, Southern brunch fare, and cocktails in a relaxed atmosphere. From their website, 'Ruby Slipper Cafe is an award-winning cafe famous for our breakfast, brunch, and lunch offerings. We bring New Orleans flair to southern breakfast standards, brunch classics, and fresh lunch dishes. We were founded in New Orleans, Louisiana, in 2008.' NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Saba
posts.note: Saba is a casual bistro with family-style platters of locally sourced Middle Eastern fare with outdoor dining. From the New Orleans Eater website, 'Saba will serve “new and improved pita” from a wood-burning oven at the center of the dining room, skewers cooked over a charcoal grill, and a host of Israeli dishes with Louisiana influences. Saba’s menu will take particular advantage of local seafood in options like hummus topped with crab meat and a fried oyster po’ boy served in a pita.'

posts.name: The Sazerac Bar
posts.note: The Sazerac Bar is a located in the Grand Roosevelt Hotel cocktail bar with classic drinks, plush banquettes, and elegant old-world vibe.

posts.name: Shaya
posts.note: Shaya celebrates the abundance of Lebanon with guest chef Fariiz Choumali. Born and raised in Beirut, chef Fariiz brings his heritage to the table. With international experience and a passion for cooking, this dinner will focus on the traditional Lebanese family meal with shared mezze courses and individual entree courses. Zahara Dimassi has carefully curated the beverage menu with Lebanese based drinks for each course. They use an Italian wood-fired pizza oven to make their fresh pita. Order the Lutenitsa which is roasted peppers and eggplant or Ikra whipped cream cheese, paddlefish caviar, shallot or the hummus on top with pita bread or for desert Babka king cake spiced streusel, cinnamon, salted caramel, mascarpone gelato.

posts.name: Slim Goodies Diner
posts.note: Slim Goodies Diner is a cash-only daytime diner with vegetarian-friendly comfort fare in funky digs with a leafy backyard. From their website, 'Opened in 2002, Slim Goodies Diner came from a deeply rooted New Orleans background. The diners mission is to share the iconic cultural creole food and service standards that New Orleans is known.'

posts.name: Snake and Jake's Christmas Club Lounge
posts.note: Snake and Jake's Christmas Club Lounge is a dive bar set in a shack-like setting with late hours, year-round retro holiday decor and a jukebox.

posts.name: Stein's Market and Deli
posts.note: Stein's Market and Deli is a Jewish-Italian market drawing crowds with specialty meats, cheeses, and a unique selection of brews. From their website, 'Welcome to Stein’s Market and Deli, a Jewish and Italian deli located in the Lower Garden District of New Orleans. Stein’s Deli offers traditional and specialty sandwiches using top-quality meats and cheeses, in addition to serving breakfast sandwiches (on Davidovich bagels from New York City) all day. You’ll find a very large selection of cured meats and salamis, and over 50 cheeses from around the world. Our retail shelves are lined with a variety of specialty goods such as aged balsamic vinegars, oils, rice and pastas, salts, seasonings, loose-leaf teas, coffees, and a huge selection of domestic and international craft beers.'
posts.rcmmnd: The Fermented Man: A Year on the Front Lines of a Food Revolution - by Derek Dellinger

posts.name: Three Legged Dog
posts.note: Three Legged Dog is an old-school, 24-hour bar serving classic pub grub plus local specialties like boiled crawfish.

posts.name: Turkey and the Wolf
posts.note: Turkey and the Wolf is a playful option for inventive sandwiches and cocktails served in a quirky, colorful space. Order the tacos inauthenticos which are made from hog's headcheese, jalapenos, shrettuce, sour cream, Valentina, American cheese on Migdalia's handmade corn tortillas or the vegetarian Rueben with collard greens or for dessert get the soft serve ice cream with cheese straws or magic shell and tater sticks, frosty style.

posts.name: Walker's BBQ
posts.note: Walker's BBQ is a cash-only counter-serve smokehouse serves famed po' boys plus BBQ standards till they run out. Walker's Southern Style BBQ is serving all your bbq favorites, ribs, chicken, brisket, and pork, along with delicious sides, like smothered mustard greens and potato salad, made in-house daily.

posts.name: Willie Mae's Scotch House
posts.note: Willie Mae's Scotch House is a lauded family-owned spot since 1957, famous for fried chicken and other soul food in a humble setting.
